title: New images of PlayStation 5 leak online - and they confirm key design feature
text:

It’s one of the most highly-anticipated gaming consoles in history, and now images of what could be the PlayStation 5 have leaked online.

LetsGoDigital has revealed new renders of the dev kit for the console, which are based on a spy shot received by Zone of Tech.

The images indicate that the console will have a V-shaped design - a feature that has been heavily rumoured.

The back of the console could have five buttons - ‘On Standby’, ‘Reset’, ‘Eject’, ‘System Initialisation’ and ‘Network Initialisation.’

Immediately below these buttons is a disk drive, which Sony has confirmed will also support Blu-ray discs.

Meanwhile, the back of the console also appears to have six USB ports, as well as a round On/Off button.

(Image: Playstation)

LetsGoDigital added: “A few details have also become visible that were not visible on the patent drawings.

“For example, a series of light indicators have been installed on the left, with the numbers; 7 - 6 - 5 - 4 - 3 - 2 - 1 - 0. Immediately below is a status light with Status 2 and Status 1. Finally, the top left of the device says 'Prototype 1 Not for Sale’.”

While Sony is yet to confirm any features for the PlayStation 5, it has finally confirmed the name, as well as a Holiday 2020 launch date.

(Image: Playstation)

In a blog about the news, Jim Ryan , President and CEO of SIE, said: “Since we originally unveiled our next-generation console in April, we know that there’s been a lot of excitement and interest in hearing more about what the future of games will bring.

“Today I’m proud to share that our next-generation console will be called PlayStation 5, and we’ll be launching in time for Holiday 2020.”

In the blog, Mr Ryan also revealed some of the key innovations to expect in the PlayStation 5 controller.

The first innovation is haptic feedback, which will replace the ‘rumble’ technology in current controllers.

Mr Ryan explained: “With haptics, you truly feel a broader range of feedback, so crashing into a wall in a race car feels much different than making a tackle on the football field.

“You can even get a sense for a variety of textures when running through fields of grass or plodding through mud.”

Secondly, Sony is including ‘adaptive triggers’ in the controller’s trigger buttons.

Mr Ryan added: “Developers can program the resistance of the triggers so that you feel the tactile sensation of drawing a bow and arrow or accelerating an off-road vehicle through rocky terrain.

“In combination with the haptics, this can produce a powerful experience that better simulates various actions.”
